title: Bob Asher (American football)
text:
Robert Dabney Asher is a former professional <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="offensive%20tackle">offensive tackle</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> for the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> and <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Vanderbilt%20University">Vanderbilt University</a>.
Early years.
Asher attended <a href="Bishop%20Denis%20J.%20O%27Connell%20High%20School">Bishop Denis J. O'Connell High School</a> where he practiced <a href="basketball">basketball</a> until his junior year, when he began playing <a href="American%20football">football</a>. He also practiced <a href="track%20%26amp%3B%20field">track</a> and <a href="tennis">tennis</a>.
He accepted a football scholarship from <a href="Vanderbilt%20University">Vanderbilt University</a>, where he started in every game during his three years of eligibility. As a junior, he was named All-South and second-team <a href="Southeastern%20Conference">All-SEC</a>.
As a senior, he received first-team <a href="Southeastern%20Conference">All-SEC</a> and second-team <a href="All-American">All-American</a> honors. He also played in the <a href="Chicago%20College%20All-Star%20Game">Chicago College All-Star Game</a>, the <a href="North%E2%80%93South%20Shrine%20Game">North–South Shrine Game</a>, the <a href="Senior%20Bowl">Senior Bowl</a> and the Canadian American Bowl.
Professional career.
Dallas Cowboys.
During the <a href="1970%20NFL%20Draft">1970 NFL Draft</a>, the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> traded <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a> <a href="Phil%20Clark%20%28American%20football%29">Phil Clark</a> and <a href="running%20back">running back</a> <a href="Craig%20Baynham">Craig Baynham</a> to the <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a>, in exchange for a second round draft choice (27th overall), that the team used to select Asher.
He injured his knee as a rookie and played in only 6 games. Doctors thought he could avoid surgery, but had to eventually perform the procedure in <a href="1971%20NFL%20season">1971</a>, which would cost him a chance to start and play in <a href="Super%20Bowl%20VI">Super Bowl VI</a>. The team placed him on the <a href="injured%20reserve%20list">injured reserve list</a> and replaced him by signing future hall of famer <a href="Forrest%20Gregg">Forrest Gregg</a>.
On August 17, <a href="1972%20NFL%20season">1972</a>, he was traded to the <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> along with <a href="defensive%20tackle">defensive tackle</a> <a href="Bill%20Line">Bill Line</a> and a second round draft choice (#48-<a href="Gary%20Hrivnak">Gary Hrivnak</a>), in exchange for <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> <a href="Jack%20Concannon">Jack Concannon</a>.
Chicago Bears.
In <a href="1972%20NFL%20season">1972</a>, he became the starter at <a href="Tackle%20%28American%20and%20Canadian%20football%29">right tackle</a>. In <a href="1975%20NFL%20season">1975</a>, he was passed over on the depth chart by <a href="Jeff%20Sevy">Jeff Sevy</a>. He retired in <a href="1976%20NFL%20season">1976</a>, after suffering from knee and calf injuries.
